@dclim I refactored the code a little bit and took care of review comments, please have a look now. I added a unit test where next offset to be fetched is greater than the least available offset which means no resetting should happen. I could not add a UT that tests the reset as it hard to simulate data drop from kafka in UT, I tried setting the retention to a very small value for the TestBroker but did not work, please let me know if you any other idea to test this. Also, we are running this code in our metrics cluster on one of the MMs.
rebased on top of #3698, added GroupBy empty row handling to MultiValuedDimensionTest

@du00cs When using LzoBlockThriftInputFormat, the thrift jar had to be included in classpath. This is different from other cases, and you may need to add some description in documentation. After the thrift jar is added to classpath, the thrift object is successfully parsed.

@du00cs No, using config: "elephantbird.class.for.MultiInputFormat" : "${YOUR_THRIFT_CLASS_NAME}" and include jar in classpath is the only way to get it work. (because thrift deserialize is done within the elephant-bird lib)
This was fixed in #3604 but wasn't backported into 0.9.2.

@akashdw, what are you trying to accomplish with this?

Some users want relative paths on purpose, to support easy migration from one hdfs cluster to another. You can get Druid to use absolute HDFS paths by specifying an absolute path in the `druid.storage.storageDirectory` property.
Thanks @gianm for reviewing this PR. I updated the description with more details. Please check.

Can this pr be used for auto-merge segments created by kafka indexing service?

Hrm, I'm not sure about this solution actually.  The reason there wasn't a "FIRST" stage created before was because the object dependency graph is supposed to ensure that dependees are created and registered before dependers.  That seems to be getting broken here, likely because it is going through `LifecycleModule.register()` to actually bootstrap instead of the normal object dependency graph.

Can you explore if it is possible to adjust the object dependency graph so that the things which require this to be started actually depend on it?
Contributing author wants to close

@linbojin it can be used to merge segments from the Kafka indexing service by using the ingest segment firehose, but the tasks still need to be submitted manually or by an external scheduler. Hopefully in the near future the 'auto' part will be implemented, possibly by generalizing #1998 to support IndexTask.
Close this PR for now, will open it if I still need it in future

druid.broker.http.readTimeout=PT5M
druid.server.http.maxIdleTime=PT5m at historical side, and this value is druid's default value

Datasketches previously supported jdk7 so imo it should continue to do so until Druid itself moves on.

@cheddar if stage FIRST is not to be introduced, then updated patch also solves the problem.
i have to make MetadataStorage a dependency of DerbyConnector even if it is not used by that, but this ensures that DerbyMetadataStorage gets created and started upfront.

@cheddar the issue is that the dependency is a network dependency (client depends on server) but that is not expressed in the object graph, because why would it be? We could include a "fake" object graph dependency like Himanshu did in the most recent patch, but that doesn't seem obviously better than something stage-based in the lifecycle.

@himanshug would it work to have the client side retry until the server is available, so even if the server starts up "late" then things will still work? Clients should be retrying if servers are unavailable anyway.
@cheddar @nishantmonu51  I wasn't able to remove the Thread.sleep, because i wanted to automatic removal of blacklisted workers once a stipulated time elapses. The thread.sleep here is very small

Sorry for late response.
I updated the code based on the review comments.

@b-slim I don't understand your point about backward compatibility because `mapName` is optional argument and users always make LookupDimensionSpec with json  so that they just omit
 `mapName` in their spec when their lookups do not have multiple maps.
And I still think having separate `mapName` is better than combining `name` and `mapName` because user may use combining delimiter (ex. `.`) in `name` or `mapName`.
However, it makes sense that `mapName` is unclear so I changed it to `innerMapName`. Welcome any suggestion.

@gianm For escaping column and table names at SQL query creation, I use escape and quote methods of SQLTemplate in Querydsl. As I'm not familiar with SQL querying in Java, I'm not sure that this make sense.

Other updates:
- KeyValueMap is moved to namespaceParseSpec from URIExtractionNamespace.
- Dependency on commons-collections is removed by using Pair
- FlatDataParser is refactored
- NamespaceLookupIntrospectHandler is modified as suggested by @gianm

Did you write this code entirely yourself, or (partially) copied from some other project?

This kind of byte management frameworks for Java always spawn writing a lot of boilerplate code for copying/comparing/streaming/converting bytes around, in which it's very easy to make a bugs. So if introducing this abstraction, I think it should be borrowed from other project in heavy use, like Hadoop, Spark, Cassandra, Netty, because it likely has little bugs, and the set of abstractions itself is proven to work. This framework should preferably be copied into the Druid codebase, not added as a dependency.

I have updated this PR to use latest version of sketches-core and also moved it completely into a contrib extension as this can only work with java-8. now on, it should have no conflicts and people should be able to try this out.

to be honestly, partially copied from Lucene project as I ever mentioned in the google group ,and removed and rewrite  some code according to Druid. for now I rewrite the default mmap implementation , and the IndexInput interface seems to replace the ByteBuffer perfectly with the read /write/slice/seek/getFilePoint methods as I tested at my own codebase. hope that we can continue this job to work around this problem. tks for your reply.

Is this a "forever" kind of bug, or a regression?
@drcrallen forever

Disabling caching seems a little heavy handed unless there's a way to enable the old behavior where postagg sorted topN's can be cached.

I suggest making this a 0.10.0 ticket with the solution of adding `getCacheKey` to post aggregators, and having any "temporary" solution be a different ticket.
+1 on disabling caching on topNs sorted by post agg and fixing as part of 0.10.0

One more way to fix this in 0.9 can be to add another Interface CacheablePostAggregator that defines getCacheKey and have all the internal post aggs impls use it. Now in the query If the post agg is cacheable we cache the query otherwise its not cached. I think this will solve the issue without impacting performance for most of the use cases. 
Only performance impact will be for users who have defined custom post aggs via extensions, which they can work around by modifying their impls to make it cacheable.
